hanzi-su-wiki:
磁

Значения

Магнит, фарфор

Мнемоника

Камень 石, притягивающий железо как нитки 么 или сухую траву 艹, магнит. При изготовлении фарфора им удаляли железистые включения.

heisig_chinese_memo: Magnetism sometimes comes in the form of a rock with two sides
heisig_constituent: magnet, stone, rock, double-mysterious, mothballs, horns, one, cocoon, cocoon2
koohiiStory1: A magnet is a rock with two sides; one that mysteriously pushes and one that pulls; doubly mysterious. (see astridtops´ story).
koohiiStory2: I found some stones on the siamese twins. Turns out the stones were magnetic, and they weren´t siamese twins at all!
jp_example_words:
磁気(じき): magnetism
磁器(じき): porcelain, china
磁石(じしゃく): magnet
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: Seeing a stone and some horns on the ground next to a piece of poop and another piece of poop, you try and pick each of them up with a magnet. The magnet fails to pick up either piece of poop. The magnet doesn’t pick up the horns either. But wait! The magnet picks up the stone!
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Imagine yourself trying to pick each object up off the ground with your magnet. Hear the clink of the stone against metal as the magnet lifts it off the ground. Must be some iron in it or something.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: You’re pretty excited that you lifted something up with your magnet. Science is cool! But then you hear someone laughing behind you. It’s Jesus (じ)! Jesus was using his magic to levitate the stone all along, it wasn’t your magnet. Darn it Jesus! You’ve fooled me for the last time!
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine Jesus snickering behind you as the stone falls to the ground once again. Imagine running after Jesus so you can catch him and give him a piece of your mind. He’s always playing tricks on you.

humanum_full_description_en:
From the " stone " to the sound of " zi ". The " magnetism " of the magnet is written as " kindness ". The ancients used the magnet to attract iron to compare it with the loving mother and the child. Later, a " stone " was added to differentiate into "礠". "Guang Yun": "Liu, the stone can lead the needle." " Liu " is simplified to " magnetism ." "Jiyun": "Liu, stone name, you can lead the needle. Also state name. Or province." "Hongwu Zhengyun": "The magnetic book makes the jade, the province is from the Zi." Magnet is a natural magnet. For example, "Huainanzi. "Lan Ming": "If you use the power of a magnet to connect iron, and ask for it to attract tiles, it will be difficult." Gu Kuang of the Tang Dynasty "Guangling Baisha Dayun Temple Stele": "Magnet takes iron, not feathers."

" Ci " is the name of an ancient state, in today's Ci County, Hebei Province. Cizhou Kiln is one of the famous folk kilns in Song Dynasty. The porcelain products produced in this kiln were called "magnets", which later referred to all porcelain products. Ming Metabolism Zhaozhe "Five Miscellaneous Cu. Wubu 4": "Today's kiln ware is called the "cizhou ware", and the Cizhou kiln in Henan is the most, so it is also named." For example, "A Dream of Red Mansions" Chapter 37: "It's just gold, jade, copper, and porcelain, nowhere An antique left."
humanum_short_description_en: From the " stone " to the " z " sound. The magnet is written as "love stone," and the ancients compared it with the loving mother and child by using the magnet to attract iron. Later, " ci " was added to " stone " to differentiate into "礠", which was simplified to " magnetism ". Magnet is a natural magnetite.
humanum_full_description:
從「石」，「茲」聲。磁石的「磁」本寫作「慈」，古人以磁石引鐵與慈母愛子相比。後來加「石」旁分化出「礠」。《廣韻》：「礠，礠石可引針也。」「礠」又簡化為「磁」。《集韻》：「礠，石名，可以引鍼。又州名。或省。」《洪武正韻》：「磁本作礠，省从茲。」磁石是一種天然的吸鐵石。用例如《淮南子．覽冥》：「若以磁石之能連鐵也，而求其引瓦，則難矣。」唐代顧況〈廣陵白沙大雲寺碑〉：「磁石攝鐵，不攝鴻毛。」

　　「磁」是古州名，在今河北省磁縣。磁州窰是宋代民間著名瓷窯之一。該窰出產的瓷製品稱為「磁器」，後來又泛指所有瓷製品。明代謝肇淛《五雜俎．物部四》：「今俗語窯器謂之磁器者，蓋河南磁州窯最多，故相沿名之。」例如《紅樓夢》第37回：「總不過是那些金、玉、銅、磁器，沒處撂的古董兒。」
humanum_short_description: 從「石」，「茲」聲。磁石本寫作「慈石」，古人以磁石引鐵與慈母愛子相比。後來「慈」加上「石」旁分化出「礠」，又簡化為「磁」。磁石是一種天然的吸鐵石。

磁石(じしゃく): magnet
從「 石 」，「 茲 」聲。磁石的「 磁 」本寫作「 慈 」，古人以磁石引鐵與慈母愛子相比。後來加「 石 」旁分化出「 礠 」。《廣韻》：「礠，礠石可引針也。」「 礠 」又簡化為「 磁 」。《集韻》：「礠，石名，可以引鍼。又州名。或省。」《洪武正韻》：「磁本作礠，省从茲。」磁石是一種天然的吸鐵石。用例如《淮南子．覽冥》：「若以磁石之能連鐵也，而求其引瓦，則難矣。」唐代顧況〈廣陵白沙大雲寺碑〉：「磁石攝鐵，不攝鴻毛。」 「 磁 」是古州名，在今河北省磁縣。磁州窰是宋代民間著名瓷窯之一。該窰出產的瓷製品稱為「磁器」，後來又泛指所有瓷製品。明代謝肇淛《五雜俎．物部四》：「今俗語窯器謂之磁器者，蓋河南磁州窯最多，故相沿名之。」例如《紅樓夢》第37回：「總不過是那些金、玉、銅、磁器，沒處撂的古董兒。」
From the " stone" to the sound of " zi". The " magnetism" of the magnet is written as " kindness". The ancients used the magnet to attract iron to compare it with the loving mother and the child. Later, a " stone" was added to differentiate into " 礠". "Guang Yun": "Liu, the stone can lead the needle." " Liu" is simplified to " magnetism." "Jiyun": "Liu, stone name, you can lead the needle. Also state name. Or province." "Hongwu Zhengyun": "The magnetic book makes the jade, the province is from the Zi." Magnet is a natural magnet. For example, "Huainanzi. "Lan Ming": "If you use the power of a magnet to connect iron, and ask for it to attract tiles, it will be difficult." Gu Kuang of the Tang Dynasty "Guangling Baisha Dayun Temple Stele": "Magnet takes iron, not feathers." " Ci" is the name of an ancient state, in today's Ci County, Hebei Province. Cizhou Kiln is one of the famous folk kilns in Song Dynasty. The porcelain products produced in this kiln were called "magnets", which later referred to all porcelain products. Ming Metabolism Zhaozhe "Five Miscellaneous Cu. Wubu 4": "Today's kiln ware is called the "cizhou ware", and the Cizhou kiln in Henan is the most, so it is also named." 磁字的基本解释

磁
cí
物质能吸引铁、镍等金属的性质：磁性。磁力。磁石。磁极。磁场。磁化。磁能。磁感应。
同“瓷”。

磁字的汉语字典释义

[①]［cí］
［《集韻》牆之切，平之，從。］
亦作“礠1”。
(1)物体能吸引铁、镍、钴等物质的性能。参见“磁石”。
(2)见“磁實”。
(3)指瓷器。

磁字的英文翻译

◎ 磁
magnetism

磁字的康熙字典解释

【午集下】【石字部】　磁； 康熙笔画：15； 页码：页834第14
【廣韻】疾之切【集韻】【韻會】牆之切【正韻】才資切，?音慈。本作礠。省从茲。【說文】石名。可以引鍼。【本草】山之陽產鐵者，隂必有礠石，蓋二物同氣也。【文選·曹植矯志詩】磁石引鐵，於今不連。【水經注】鎬水，北經漢靈臺西，又經磁石門西，門在阿房前。　又【韻會】州名。古邯鄲地，隋置礠州，唐改惠州，尋復爲磁。【前漢·藝文志】作慈。

磁字的源字形

磁字的起名意思

意指磁石，磁性。

Basic explanation of words
magnetic
cí
The property of a substance that can attract metals such as iron and nickel: magnetism. magnetic force. magnet. magnetic pole. magnetic field. magnetization. Magnetic energy. Magnetic induction.
Same as "porcelain".
magnetic
Chinese dictionary definition of words
[①]［cí］
["Jiyun" wall cut, flat, from. ]
Also known as "礠1".
(1) The object's ability to attract iron, nickel, cobalt and other substances. See "magnet".
(2) See "Magnetic Reality".
(3) Refers to porcelain.

[Guang Yun] Cut of the disease [Ji Yun] [Rhyme] Cut of the wall [Zheng Yun] Only talented cut,? Yinci. This work is 礠. Province from here. [Said the text] The name of the stone. Can lead the needle. [Materia Medica] For those who produce iron in the yang of the mountain, the yin must have stone, and the two things have the same air. In the ancient Handan area, the Sui Dynasty set up Lianzhou, and the Tang Dynasty changed to Huizhou, seeking to revert to magnetism. [Previous Han·Art and Literature History] Being a kindness.

magnetic
Name meaning
Means magnet, magnetic.
磁
形声字。石表意,其形像山崖下有块石头,表示具有磁性的石头;兹(五)表声,兹有产生意表示磁是能产生吸力的磁
石。本义是磁石(吸铁石),又指磁性。
①能吸引铁、镍等金属的性能:~铁|~力。②通“瓷”。

~头 ~心 ~性 ~针 充~ 地~ 电~ 防~
|磁
磁
隶
楷
магнитный
Пиктофонетические символы.
Камень выражает значение, его форма подобна камню под обрывом, что означает камень с магнетизмом; тем самым (5) выражает звук и, таким образом, означает, что магнетизм является магнитом, который может создавать притяжение.
Первоначальное значение - магнит (магнит), также оно относится к магнетизму.
① Способность притягивать металлы, такие как железо и никель: ~ железо | ~ сила.
②Через «Фарфор».

| Магнитный
магнитный
писец
Кай
cí
1) магнит; магнитный
磁罗盘 магнитный компас
磁子午线 магнитный меридиан
2) фарфор, фаянс; керамика; фарфоровый, керамический
磁坩埚 фарфоровый тигель
磁很细 фарфор очень тонок, керамика очень изящна
3) (сокр. вм. 磁铁矿) магнитный железняк, магнетит
Radicals: 石, 一, 幺  (stone, ground, poop, horns)
Meaning Mnemonic
Seeing a stone and some horns on the ground next to a piece of poop and another piece of poop, you try and pick each of them up with a magnet. The magnet fails to pick up either piece of poop. The magnet doesn’t pick up the horns either. But wait! The magnet picks up the stone!
Imagine yourself trying to pick each object up off the ground with your magnet. Hear the clink of the stone against metal as the magnet lifts it off the ground. Must be some iron in it or something.
Reading Mnemonic
You’re pretty excited that you lifted something up with your magnet. Science is cool! But then you hear someone laughing behind you. It’s Jesus (じ)! Jesus was using his magic to levitate the stone all along, it wasn’t your magnet. Darn it Jesus! You’ve fooled me for the last time!
Imagine Jesus snickering behind you as the stone falls to the ground once again. Imagine running after Jesus so you can catch him and give him a piece of your mind. He’s always playing tricks on you.
